Faith

Cyber Security Student at Curtin University. I regularly participate in CTFs and bug bounties. I love pwn and RE challenges :D
  • HTB

Cyber Security Blog

October 12th, 2019

picoCTF 2019: Ghost_Diary

A heap exploitation challenge on glibc 2.27. The only vulnerability is a single null byte overflow when editing the contents of a malloc’d chunk. I used that null byte overflow to call malloc_consolidate() and get overlapped chunks, followed by a libc leak. Then it was just a normal tcache poisoning attack to get a chunk onto __free_hook, overwrite it with a one gadget, then call free() to get a shell. The hardest part about this challenge is that its glibc 2.27, meaning the tcache is enabled. We get past that in a very novel (not really) way, as shown in the writeup.

September 16th, 2019

CSAW Qualifiers 2019: small_boi

Very tiny binary. I used SigReturn Oriented Programming (SROP) to exploit it.

September 16th, 2019

CSAW Qualifiers 2019: baby_boi

This binary had a very simple stack buffer overflow with NX enabled. It required a ret2libc attack, however calling system once didn’t work because of the condition the stack was in, so I had to add more input into the payload to create a valid stack frame. More information in the writeup.

September 8th, 2019

DefCamp Qualifiers 2019: secret

This binary had a format string vulnerability + a stack buffer overflow vulnerability. We use the format string vulnerability to leak the stack canary and a libc address from the stack. Calculate libc base address then find the address of system and a /bin/sh string, then call system("/bin/sh") to get a shell.

September 8th, 2019

DefCamp Qualifiers 2019: get-access

A classic blind format string challenge where you had to dump the entire binary to get the flag.

August 26th, 2019

HackCon 2019: babypwn

A binary that doesn’t require EIP control to exploit it. It has none of the obvious vulnerabilities (buffer overflow, format string, etc) but does have a very specific vulnerability that you had to find through reverse engineering.

August 23rd, 2019

HackCon 2019: Not So Easy Bof

A binary with a format string and a stack buffer overflow vulnerability with all protection mechanisms enabled.

July 28th, 2019

Regex-based Blind SQL Injection Attacks

A guide detailing how a blind SQL injection attack works. It uses my Philips and Over challenge writeup from PeaCTF 2019 Qualifiers as an example.

July 28th, 2019

PeaCTF Qualifiers (13th Place): All Challenges

PeaCTF was a CTF created for high school students, so it’s a little bit on the easier side. I ended at 13th place, finishing all challenges.

July 19th, 2019

ROP Emporium Challenges

I started doing the challenges from ROP Emporium because I wanted to start really learning about Return Oriented Programming. These are my writeups for the challenges. More will be added as I do them.
